Through part of the Gettysburg battle ground; Louise mounts a Northern cannon.
Three hours with Nancy in Charlottesville where she is attending summer school at the University of Virginia.
Kathy and Louisa inspect the town with Annette Vail, Nancy's roommate.
Rotunda of the University, founded in 1819 by Thomas Jefferson.

blocks.text: The capitol of West Virginia in Charleston, one of the most attractive of all state capitol buildings; viewed from across the Kanawha River. Although West Virginia generally is considered a poor state, Charleston enjoys one of the highest per capita incomes in the nation, due to extensive industrial locations up and down the Kanawha valley.
Through Kentucky's Bluegrass country near Lexington where some of world's finest thoroughbred horses are raised amidst luxuriant surroundings.
Kathy and Louise in motel appear fit and fresh after two days' of travel.
Unloading the car for the second night's stay at this motel near Versailles, Ky.

blocks.text: THIRD DAY, Thursday, July 6, 1961; Versailles, Ky. to Van Buren, Mo.; 7:25 A. M. to 7:35 P. M; 418 miles; total 1,096 miles.
Bridge across the Kentucky River...we are in bourbon country.
Stephen Foster is said to have written his Old Kentucky Home in 1852 while he and his wife were visiting their cousin John Rowan at his estate called Federal Hill, near Bardstown.
Music by Stephen Fossteer is played intermittently as we explore the grounds.
John Rowan was a wealthy planter and statesman who lies buried in a small cemetery on the estate. It is interesting to note that John Rowan came to Kentucky from York County, Pennsylvania.

blocks.text: Two hydroelectric dams close together east of Paducah: the Barkley Dam is under construction across the Cumberland River; the Kentucky Dam is across the Tennessee River. Many millions of dollars have gone into their creation.
At the extreme southern end of Illinois is Cairo Point, where the Ohio River flows into the Mississippi. Bridge at left is across the Ohio; that at right crosses the Mississippi.

Night at Van Buren,
Ozarks. Bookmobile brings literature to the mountain people.
Mo. in heart of the Mcc., Inn, heart of the Ozarks.
Flat eastern Missouri...encounter heavy rain.

blocks.text: FOURTH DAY, Friday, July 7, 1961; Van Buren, Mo. to Claremore, Okla.; total 2:30 P.M.; 306 miles; total 1,402 miles. .
The Ozarks are generally heavily wooded and sparsely settled. The mountaineers are of pure English and Scotch stock who have retained their old ways to a remarkable degree.
A quick lunch at this roadside stand at the extreme southwestern corner of Missouri. We call the Ty Cobb family, old friendsss... in Claremore, Okla., who urge us to visit them.
Beyond the mountains, we approach Spring-field. Speed limit is generous. Later, at busy entrance to Joplin, tire blows out.

Speeded at 70 miles an hour on Oklahoma (Will Rogers) Turnpike to Claremore. Restaurant over Turnpike only place in U.S. we have seen restaurant so constructed.
Restaurantrant
Restaurant Turnpike to Claremore. Speeded at 70 miles an hour on
Through three miles of Kansas to reach the Oklahoma Turnpike.

blocks.text: FIFTH DAY, Saturday, July 8, 1961; Claremore, Okla. to Clayton, N. M.; 7:10 A. M. to 7:25 P. M; 476 miles; total 1,878 miles.
Westward again across the Oklahoma plains, a region of great loneliness, but rich in oil, wheat and cattle. There are few trees. Beyond Kitty a pumper brings forth the "black gold".
The Indian population of Oklahoma is the largest of any state, representing thirty tribes.
After four hours of heavy rainfall in the Oklahoma Panhandle, which floods the road in several places, we finally emerge into the sunshine and leave the black clouds behind us.

blocks.text: SIXTH DAY, Sunday, July 9, 1961; Clayton, N. M. to Santa Fe, N. M.; 7:00 A. M. to 6:20 P. M; 296 miles; total 2,174 miles.

RABBIT EAR MOUNTAIN
[The rest of the text on the signpost in the image is not fully legible due to resolution and angle.]
The mist rises, the sun appears and disclosed are flat-topped mountains, so strange to those who see them for the first time. Cattle graze over a wide area.

Capulin Mountain, established as a national monument in 1916, is located in northeast New Mexico. It is a large volcanic cinder cone which was active about 2000 years ago. Rising 1500 feet from the surrounding plain, it is visible from great distances. A road has been constructed to the top (see picture above).
At the rim of the crater we meet Judge Carpenter and his family, from Big Spring, Texas. Having attended a convention there in 1949, we discuss mutual acquaintances.

blocks.text: Northward toward the town of Raton, with the Rocky Mountains of Colorado in the distance.
Southwestward toward Cimarron with the Rockies to the north constantly in view. Nearby is the Philmont Boy Scout Ranch, for Scouts from all parts of the country. Lunchtime.
A circuitous route from Eagle Nest to cross spectacular Red River Pass at 9852 feet. The road sign gives a good indication of the sharpness of the curves.

blocks.text: Taos, 70 miles north of Santa Fe, in the heart of the mountains, has become the center of an art colony where there is a pleasing blending of Spanish, Indian and American cultures. The cemetery (probably Spanish-American) is gaily decorated.

Close to Taos village is Taos Pueblo, the Indian village. Modern adobe buildings have been erected at the entrance by the Catholic Church. As you enter an Indian meets you to collect an admission fee, plus a special charge for each camera you plan to use. It is soon learned that each Indian you photograph expects his special fee.

pages.full_text:
Taos, 70 miles north of Santa Fe, in the heart of the mountains, has become the center of an art colony where there is a pleasing blending of Spanish, Indian and American cultures. The cemetery (probably Spanish-American) is gaily decorated.

Close to Taos village is Taos Pueblo, the Indian village. Modern adobe buildings have been erected at the entrance by the Catholic Church. As you enter an Indian meets you to collect an admission fee, plus a special charge for each camera you plan to use. It is soon learned that each Indian you photograph expects his special fee.

blocks.text: The famous Tao's Pueblo, Indian community house which holds numerous families, stands today much as it did when the Spaniards first came here in 1540.

After Gordon had taken the picture above, he was approached by a noisy Indian hag who demanded 50¢ for having her picture taken. Despite denials, she began to curse and throw stones. She got no money. The picture does not include her presence. It may have been worth the fee to catch her in action.

blocks.text: SEVENTH DAY, Monday, July 10, 1961; Santa Fe, N. M. to Silverton, Colo; 10:20 A. M. to 6:30 P. M.; 264 miles; total 2,438 miles.

Santa Fe, second oldest city in the U. S. (after St. Augustine) was founded in 1610 by the Spaniards, who from here ruled an empire that stretched from the Mississippi to the Pacific. Americans occupied the city in 1846. Adobe construction predominates, even to public buildings.
We spend most of the morning in shopping and inspecting the city.
Distinctive new state capitol (right) completed in 1953.
All buildings around the Plaza, including modern stores, show adobe influence.

blocks.text: Kittity, wiith some streetching, shows that this is indeed a narrow-gage railroad.

The ancient buildings of Silverton are being restored. The old structures have been preserved and renovated with care to maintain their historical charm while making them accessible for modern visitors.
Restoration efforts in the town center reveal a blend of traditional architecture, showcasing intricate woodwork and stone masonry that speaks volumes about its rich history. These renovations not only preserve but also enhance Silverton's appeal as a tourist destination, drawing people from far and wide to explore this charming locale.
The project aims to create an environment where visitors can immerse themselves in the town’s past while enjoying modern amenities. This balance between preservation and progress ensures that future generations will continue to appreciate and learn about Silverton’s heritage.
In conclusion, these restoration efforts are a testament to our commitment towards preserving historical sites for cultural enrichment and tourism promotion alike.

blocks.text: Black Canyon of the Gunnison River - a National Monument - where the river has cut a wedge-shaped gorge through a high plateau whose walls rise to almost 3,000' at highest point, and in places they appear almost to touch. As the name indicates, the rock surfaces are black. At spot Kitty is seated (top picture). The drop is a sheer 1,800'. Entrance is 13 miles east of Montrose.

blocks.text: Northwest of Delta, unexpectedly we are in semi-desert.

Colorado National Monument, near Grand Junction,
contains 18,000 acres of eroded mesa, some of the most impressive examples of erosion in America.
The Rimrock Drive discloses 1,000 foot deep canyons, towering monoliths and stratified columns. Red color predominates.

As we climb the very steep road to the top the engine of the car overheats, and all the water boils out. We return to the valley to get new water, try again and manage to reach the top. From here on during the rest of the trip the car overheats at the slightest effort, in spite of a number of attempts to secure repairs.

blocks.text: NINTH DAY, Wednesday, July 12, 1961; Monticello, Utah to Cameron, Ariz.; 7:15 A. M. to 4:40 P. M; 235 miles; total 3,022 miles.
Wild, rough country as we head south through the very southeastern part of Utah. There are two small towns of Blanding and Bluff.
A number of unbridged washes can bring real danger in event of flash floods.

These curious mountains along the San Juan River appear to be stattedified in great waves.
The SSSan Juan appears to have been stratified in great waves..

A gravel side road takes us to the overlook of the Goosesnecks of the San Juan River. Kitty is telling Louise to stay away from the edge; there are no protecting fences; the drop is a sheer 1,500 feet.

The SSSan Juan appears to have been stratified in great waves..

A gravel side road takes us to the overlook of the Goosesnecks of the San Juan River. Kitty is telling Louise to stay away from the edge; there are no protecting fences; the drop is a sheer 1,500 feet.

blocks.text: The Goosenecks, called "the convolutions of the San Juan River", stretch far as the eye can see. One of the great spectacles of America. Rarely seen by tourists.
Beyond Mexican Hat, a blow out at 60 miles per hour. Only three cars pass in 45 min., but each stops to offer assistance.

blocks.text: The Navajos are the largest Indian tribe in the United States with a population of about 70,000. They live on a 24,000 square mile reservation, largely in Arizona, but extending into New Mexico and Utah. There can be little farming on this inhospitable land, so mostly they raise sheep, usually tended by women and children. They are famous for their heavy silver jewelry and for their weaving of blankets and rugs. These are offer for sale at trading posts (one silver necklace was priced at $75). Most of them live poorly in "hogans", dome-shaped huts of logs or earth and stones. See examples above.

blocks.text: TENTH DAY, Thursday, July 13, 1961; Cameron, Ariz. to Flagstaff, Ariz.; 6:45 A.M. to 10:30 A.M.; 151 miles; total 3,173 miles.

Early in the morning we enter Grand Canyon National Park at the South Rim. This is our third trip to the Grand Canyon; in 1953 we visited the North Rim; in 1956 we viewed the Canyon from the South Rim. Louise was too young to accompany us on the first trip; all the girls were along on the second trip.

blocks.text: Louise stands in silent speculation at the awesome spectacle of the Grand Canyon (opposite page). The small print shows the exact size of the 35mm negative from which the enlargement was made.

To show the vastness of this land: Flagstaff is the seat of Coconino County, second largest county in the U. S., with an area of 19,000 square miles, equal to the area of Vermont, Massachusetts and Rhode Island combined.
ELEVENTH DAY, Friday, July 14, 1961; Flagstaff, Ariz. to St. Johns, Ariz.; 4:30 P. M. to 9:00 P. M.; July 14, 1961; 158 miles; total 3,331 miles.

The car is not ready until late afternoon. In addition to a new tire, we add a good used tire as an additional spare; have a new fuel pump; have the radiator removed and checked; have repairs made to a broken rod which holds the engine in place, apparently broken when the car fell off the jack at time of second blow out. Total bill, $164. We soon discover the engine overheats as quickly as it did before.
A few miles east of Flagstaff is Walnut Canyon National Monument, established to preserve the ruins of more than 200 prehistoric small cliff dwellings in the walls of a deep canyon.

blocks.text: We make a circle tour of the cliff dwellings, many of which have been partially restored. It is believed the Indians lived here from 900 to 1200 A. D. Why they were abandoned is a mystery, although probably due to drought conditions. At this altitude, our hike is exhausting.

blocks.text: Petried Forest, Arizona contains the world's largest and most colorful concentration of petrified wood. Giant logs of agate lie strewn about where they were deposited millions of years ago. There is also a badlands area of vari-colored hillocks. A museum contains polished specimens of the wood, with explanations of how the petrifaction occurred. It is late when we arrive and dark when we depart just in time to escape the closing of the gate

blocks.text: TWELFTH DAY, Saturday, July 15, 1961; St. Johns, Ariz. to Sierra Blanca, Texas; 6:45 A. M. to 6:50 P. M.; 419 miles; total 3,750 miles.

The dramatic change in vegetation at different altitudes is shown clearly in the pictures above. When we leave St. Johns in the early morning we are in semi-desert country (left); as we start to climb into high country (right) small trees and bushes begin to appear at the very point a certain altitude is reached.
The sign warns of a deer crossing, but that ahead is distinctly a cow and her calf. Tall trees heree..
Big game country at Alpine...the air is cool, refreshing....gas is 42¢ per gallon ...we buy (of all things) bananas.
NEW MEXICO Land of Enchantment.
Kitty amidst mountain in flowers, which we decide are prickly poppies.

blocks.text: Silver City, N. M., in the foothills of the Black Range, is one of six Old West towns with this name, and the only one to continue to grow after pay-dirt ran out; here Billy the Kid killed his first man; and here we recross the Continental Divide.
The Butterfield Field Trail, in use from 1858 to 1881, famous as the first overland stage route for mail and passengers from St. Louis to San Francisco. Flat and very hot!

As we approach Deming, N. M., in the far distance is Cooks Range and Cooks Peak. A large jack rabbit, almost the same color as the vegetation; catches our eye. In the left center is a yucca plant, state flower of N. M.

blocks.text: Bowlin's Trading Post, almost halfway between Deming and Las Cruces. This is along route 70, southernmost highway in the U.S. The Mexican border is about 30 miles to the south, with apparently little but semi-desert, and no roads in between. We visit the trading post.
A prop for the tourist's camera (Kitty).

A nasty import,
a cobra; which in our presence is fed a small, live chicken that is swallowed whole (something to dream about for a week).

blocks.text: In decided contrast with the land we have just covered, the rich, productive valley of the Rio Grande, south of Las Cruces. Organ Mountains in distance.

Finally, our first contact with the state of Texas. at the extreme western edge, as we near El Paso.
We meet Eil Passo.
Watermelon at a roadside stand in El Paso. It is extremely hot; the car overheats more and more as each stop and start, and depart soon as possible. See previous visit to El Paso in 1956.
Stop for night at this motel .just before descending pass to town of Sierra Blanca. Air conditioning not needed here; bargain - $7 for four.
After following the Rio Grande River for about 60 miles, with Mexico in view on opposite bank, highway rises to Quitman Mountain pass. Sierra Blanca Peak, bare and brown, in distance.

blocks.text: THIRTEENTH DAY, Sunday, July 16, 1961; Sierra Blanca, Texas to Giddings, Texas; 8:00 A. M. to 9:30 P. M.; 567 miles; total 4,317 miles.
Louise inspects more cacti behind a roadside wire fence.
The land turns flat... entering the Texas counterpart of the Great Plains.

Originally, plans were to drive about 200 miles south from Van Horn to Big Bend National Park, a vast and rugged region across the Rio Grande from Mexico; but with a crippled car and still more than 2,300 miles from home, we decide Big Bend must wait for another trip.

One of best and most reasonable lunches of entire trip at this small cafe in Sheffield. Upon inquiry, proprietor says shrubs covering hillside are 'grease-wood' ...must be local idiom.... can't locate the word anywhere.

blocks.text: In spite of an obstreperous car we are making remarkably good time. There are few towns and very little traffic.

Bridge across the Pecos River, in days of the Old West considered the end of civilization, for the expression, "West of the Pecos", meant beyond the realm of law and order. (Quiet enough now, with plenty of room for lots more people.)
After maintaining a steady 65-70 mile-per-hour pace on the Texas flatlands, we come to mesa country and rise to a high plateau.

pages.full_text:
In spite of an obstreperous car we are making remarkably good time. There are few towns and very little traffic.

Bridge across the Pecos River, in days of the Old West considered the end of civilization, for the expression, "West of the Pecos", meant beyond the realm of law and order. (Quiet enough now, with plenty of room for lots more people.)

After maintaining a steady 65-70 mile-per-hour pace on the Texas flatlands, we come to mesa country and rise to a high plateau.

blocks.text: Arrive in Austin, Texas, in very late evening. Present Capitol, completed in 1888 has 500 rooms, is 308 feet high....seen for first time by all of us. Actually, this picture by good lens discloses more than naked eye.
FOURTEENTH DAY, Monday, July 17, 1961; Giddings, Texas to Houma, La.; 10:00 A. M. to 8:25 P. M; 438 miles; total 4,755 miles.
After crossing Sabine River in Louisiana, Kathy and Louise for first time. Southern has prosperous-looking farms Rain in afternoon on.

Ranch land left behind; now in farm country;
Kitty (above) has just phoned the Finlaysons,
formerly from Lancaster, at edge of Houston,
largest city in Texas. Long swing to by-pass
Houston...also by-pass Beaumont.

blocks.text: We decide to leave New Orleans after several hours of sightseeing. Too hot!
Re-examine plans over sandwiches and root beer...decide to head north through state of Mississippi to Meridian, then turn east into Alabama.
Another car check in Selma...hope we can make home...new noises in transmission.

blocks.text: SIXTEENTH DAY, Wednesday, July 19; 1961: Selma, Ala. to Gastonia, N. C.; 9:05 A.M. to 10:20 P. M; 508 miles; total 5,642 miles.

From Selma, on Alabama River, to Montgomery, state capital and first capital of Confederacy. Capitol building seen by all for first time. Gordon snaps picture from middle of street while light is red.
By pure chance, pass through Royston, Ga., home of Ty Cobb, baseball great, after having heard of his death the day before on car radio.
Time out for watermelon, purchased at a wayside stand. Louise and Kathy display ravenous appetites. We consume a whole melon.

blocks.text: Recently completed Hartwell Dam across the Savannah River, between Georgia and South Carolina. (Almost dark, and raining: 1/30; fl.9).
SEVENTEENTH DAY, Thursday, July 20, 1961; Gastonia, N. C. to Lancaster, Pa; 7:25 A. M. to 10:20 P. M.; 502 miles; total 6,144 miles.

A "gas war" near Charlotte,
N. C. Regular gas is 16¢ &
Ethyl 22.9¢ per gallon. We
fill the tank.
Stop briefly again in Charlottesville to see Nancy...then, bee-line for home.
The Imperial requires an entirely new transmission, plus other repairs.

Gordon and Kitty Landreth

blocks.text: Approach from the north and cross Mt. Mansfield, 4;393', highest point in state, via Smugglers' Notch, a narrow defile through which goods were smuggled into Canada in early 19th century.

blocks.text: The hamlet of Plymouth, preserved in its simplicity as a memorial to Calvin Coolidge, is more impressive in its quiet dignity than buildings of marble or granite. Here Coolidge was born in 1872; here he spent his youth; and attended church; and here in 1923 he took the oath of office as President of the United States. In a nearby cemetery lie buried the former President, his wife and son under simple headstones.

blocks.text: The third and last night spent at this motel near Shaftsbury; engaged in a price war with neighboring motels; motel owner somewhat inebricated; we get "the best" for $6.
Our road skirts the Catskills on the way to Ellenville and Port Jervis.
Through famed Delaware Water Gap, 122 miles from home.
A final bite to eat at roadside restaurant near Bethel, Pa. Home at 6:30 P.M.
End - trip to Vermont.
